conclusion: No violation of Article 9 - Freedom of thought, conscience and religion (Article 9-1 - Manifest religion or belief);No violation of Article 2 of Protocol No. 1 - Right to education-{general} (Article 2 of Protocol No. 1 - Right to education);No violation of Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life (Article 8-1 - Respect for private life);No violation of Article 10 - Freedom of expression-{general} (Article 10-1 - Freedom of expression);No violation of Article 14+9 - Prohibition of discrimination (Article 9 - Freedom of thought, conscience and religion;Article 9-1 - Manifest religion or belief)
docname: CASE OF LEYLA ŞAHİN v. TURKEY - [Georgian Translation]
externalsources: Recommendation 1353 (1998) on the access of minorities to higher education, adopted by the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe on 27 January 1998;Recommendation no. R (98) 3 on access to higher education, adopted by the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on 17 March 1998;Joint Council of Europe/UNESCO Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications concerning Higher Education in the European Region, come into force on 1 February 1999
issue: Constitution, Articles 2, 4, 10, 13, 14, 24, 42 and 143; Higher-Education Act (Law no. 2547), transitional section 17; Students Disciplinary Procedure Rules; Circular issued by the Vice Chancellor of Istanbul University on 23 February 1998 ; Judgment of  the Constitutional Court of 9 April 1991 ; Judgment of the Supreme Administrative Court of 13 December 1984 ; Judgment of the Constitutional Court of 7 March 1989
